factoid: The coach with six horses was waiting at the porch.
The autumn night was very dark, so the coachman could not see the carriage pole.
Servants with lanterns were bustling about in the porch.
The immense house was brilliant with lights shining through its lofty windows.
The domestic serfs were crowding in the hall, waiting to bid good-by to the young prince.
Michael Ivánovich, Mademoiselle Bourienne, Princess Mary, and the little princess were all gathered in the reception hall.
Prince Andrew had been called to his father's study.
Prince Andrew's father wished to say good-by to Prince Andrew alone.
The members of the household were all waiting for Prince Andrew and his father to come out.
When Prince Andrew entered the study, the old man, wearing old-age spectacles and a white dressing gown, sat at the table writing.
The old man received no one but Prince Andrew.
The old man glanced around.
The old man asked, "Going?"
The old man continued writing.
The old man said, "I’ve come to say good-by."
The old man said, "Kiss me here."
The old man touched his cheek.
The old man said, "Thanks, thanks!"
The old man asked, "What do you thank me for?"
The old man said, "For not dilly-dallying and not hanging to a woman’s apron strings."
The old man said, "The Service before everything."
The old man said, "Thanks, thanks!"
The old man's quill spluttered and squeaked as he wrote.
The old man said, "If you have anything to say, say it."
The old man said, "These two things can be done together."
The old man said, "About my wife... I am ashamed as it is to leave her on your hands."
The old man said, "Why talk nonsense? Say what you want."
The old man said, "When her confinement is due, send to Moscow for an accoucheur. Let him be here."
The old man stopped writing.
The old man fixed his stern eyes on Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew said, "I know that no one can help if nature does not do her work."
Prince Andrew was evidently confused.
Prince Andrew said, "I know that out of a million cases only one goes wrong, but it is her fancy and mine."
Prince Andrew said, "They have been telling her things."
Prince Andrew said, "She has had a dream and is frightened."
The old man muttered, "Hm... Hm..."
The old man finished writing.
The old man said, "I’ll do it."
The old man signed with a flourish.
The old man turned to Prince Andrew and began to laugh.
The old man said, "It’s a bad business, eh?"
Prince Andrew asked, "What is bad, Father?"
The old man said, "The wife!"
Prince Andrew said, "I don’t understand!"
The old man said, "No, it can’t be helped, lad."
The old man said, "They’re all like that; one can’t unmarry."
The old man said, "Don’t be afraid; I won’t tell anyone, but you know it yourself."
The old man seized Prince Andrew by the hand with small bony fingers.
The old man shook Prince Andrew's hand.
The old man looked straight into Prince Andrew’s face with keen eyes.
The old man laughed again.
Prince Andrew sighed, admitting that his father had understood him.
The old man folded and sealed his letter, snatching up and throwing down the wax, the seal, and the paper with his accustomed rapidity.
The old man said, "What’s to be done? She’s pretty! I will do everything. Make your mind easy."
Prince Andrew did not speak.
Prince Andrew was both pleased and displeased that his father understood him.
The old man got up and gave the letter to Prince Andrew.
The old man said, "Listen!"
The old man said, "Don’t worry about your wife: what can be done shall be."
The old man said, "Now listen!"
The old man said, "Give this letter to Michael Ilariónovich."
The old man said, "I have written that Michael Ilariónovich should make use of you in proper places and not keep you long as an adjutant: a bad position!"
The old man said, "Tell Michael Ilariónovich I remember and like him."
The old man said, "Write and tell me how Michael Ilariónovich receives you."
The old man said, "If Michael Ilariónovich is all right—serve him."
The old man said, "Nicholas Bolkónski’s son need not serve under anyone if he is in disfavor."
The old man said, "Now come here."
The old man spoke so rapidly that he did not finish half his words.
Prince Andrew was accustomed to understand his father's speech.
The old man led Prince Andrew to the desk.
The old man raised the desk lid.
The old man drew out a drawer.
The old man took out an exercise book filled with his bold, tall, close handwriting.
